senses.de: To show or tell how you feel or what you are thinking
senses.ex: She expressed her concern for her friend's safety.

Tips.title: Emotional Depth
Tips.description: Use 'express' to convey deep feelings, often with emphasis or intensity.
Tips.example: She couldn't help but express her joy with a loud cheer.

Tips.title: Beyond Words
Tips.description: Remember expressions can be non-verbal, like facial expressions or gestures.
Tips.example: His silent hug expressed more than words ever could.

Tips.title: Public vs. Private
Tips.description: When you express feelings, it can be either in private or to an audience.
Tips.example: During the meeting, she chose to publicly express her gratitude.

senses.de: To represent in words, express clearly
senses.ex: He found it difficult to express his feelings in words.

Tips.title: Clarity Matters
Tips.description: When expressing views, being clear and concise helps convey your message.
Tips.example: He expressed his views on the policy with clear, persuasive points.

Tips.title: Personal Perspective
Tips.description: Use 'express' to share your unique thoughts and opinions on a topic.
Tips.example: In her essay, she expressed her personal perspective on climate change.

senses.de: Made or done for a particular purpose
senses.ex: We went to the village for the express purpose of buying food.

Tips.title: Specific Intention
Tips.description: An 'express' purpose is deliberate, with a clear and defined goal.
Tips.example: The fund was created with the express purpose of aiding disaster victims.

Tips.title: Implied Urgency
Tips.description: 'Express' can suggest something is a high priority or needs immediate attention.
Tips.example: The general gave an express order to retreat to safe ground.

senses.ex: She took the express train to the city center.

Tips.title: Speed Importance
Tips.description: Use 'express' when indicating that something is faster than the usual options.
Tips.example: I used express shipping to receive the package tomorrow.

Tips.title: Direct Route
Tips.description: An 'express' service usually takes the most direct path or means fewer stops.
Tips.example: The express bus doesn't stop in the suburbs, only in major cities.

senses.de: To squeeze out a liquid while exerting pressure
senses.ex: The doctor needs to express the pus from the abscess.

Tips.title: Medical Procedure
Tips.description: In medical contexts, 'express' refers to extracting fluids with careful action.
Tips.example: The nurse will express the wound to clean it properly.

Tips.title: Parental Care
Tips.description: Mothers 'express' breast milk to store for feeding their babies later.
Tips.example: She expressed milk before leaving for work.

Articulate.wordDefinition:
Articulate means to express oneself clearly and effectively in speech or writing, usually in a more formal or academic setting.

For example, a teacher might ask a student to articulate their opinions on a particular topic in a class discussion.

Articulate is specifically about expressing oneself in a clear and effective way, while express is a broader term that encompasses any form of communication.

Communicate.wordDefinition:
The words communicate and express are closely related and often used interchangeably, but there is a subtle difference between them.

Communicate refers to the act of sharing information or ideas with someone else through language, body language, or other means.

Communication can take many forms, such as talking, writing, gesturing, or using technology.

It emphasizes the individual's personal experience and their desire to express themselves in a meaningful way. Expressing oneself can be done for various reasons, such as to communicate a message, to evoke a response, or to simply share one's inner world with others.

Communicate describes the act of sharing information, while express describes the act of conveying personal thoughts and emotions.

Communication is more objective and focused on conveying a message, while expression is more subjective and focused on sharing personal experiences.

Convey.wordDefinition:
The words convey and express both mean to communicate something, but there is a slight difference in how they are used.

Convey means to transport or carry something, like a message or idea, from one place to another. It’s often used when talking about transferring information in a clear and effective way, like conveying instructions or conveying emotions through art.

Express means to convey something in a specific way or through a specific medium, like using words, images or body language.

If you want to get a message across effectively, you would use convey. If you want to communicate your feelings or ideas in a specific way, you would use express.

Declare.wordDefinition:
Declare means to make something known officially or publicly. This is usually done through a formal statement or an announcement.

For example, a government might declare a national holiday or a company might declare bankruptcy.

Declare is used more for official or public announcements, and express is used more for conveying emotions or ideas in a clear way.

Pronounce.wordDefinition:
Pronounce means to say or articulate a word correctly.

Express is the act of communicating while pronounce is the act of saying a word properly.

Speak.wordDefinition:
Speak means to convey or communicate a message using spoken words, either in conversation or through public speaking. It is applicable in situations where a person wants to share information or have a discussion with others, such as giving a presentation or participating in a debate.

Express is more focused on the creative aspect of communication, while speak is more focused on verbal communication.

State.wordDefinition:
State means to make a definite or authoritative declaration. For example, "The Prime Minister stated that the government will take strict action against corruption.".

Both words can be used interchangeably, but express is usually used in informal situations where the speaker wants to communicate their own thoughts and feelings, while state is used in more formal situations where the speaker wants to make an authoritative statement, such as in a legal or official document.

Utter.wordDefinition:
Both express and utter mean to communicate or convey something verbally or in writing.

Utter, on the other hand, is a more general term that simply means to say or speak something aloud.

It doesn't necessarily imply the same level of clarity or intentionality as express. For example, you might utter a curse word when you stub your toe, without really thinking too much about what you're saying.

Express is generally used when the speaker wants to communicate something specific and meaningful, while utter is a more neutral term that applies to any kind of spoken communication.

Voice.wordDefinition:
Voice refers to the sound produced when we speak, but it can also refer to the way we express ourselves, our unique perspective or point of view.

This word is often used when you want to talk about someone's opinions or beliefs, such as giving someone a voice in a conversation or giving a platform for a specific voice to be heard.

Express is used when talking about how we say something, while voice is used when talking about what we have to say.

quotes.Text: There are really two core principles at play here. There's giving people a voice so that people can express their opinions. Then, there's keeping the community safe, which I think is really important. We're not gonna let people plan violence or attack each other or do bad things.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Mark Zuckerberg

quotes.Text: I need to let people know who I am and instead of just trying to make great records, just be honest and make it more personal and make it more passionate, to make records with emotion and not be afraid to express that.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Future

quotes.Text: No stream rises higher than its source. What ever man might build could never express or reflect more than he was. He could record neither more nor less than he had learned of life when the buildings were built.
quotes.Title: American Architect
quotes.Name: Frank Lloyd Wright

quotes.Text: Beauty has as many meanings as man has moods. Beauty is the symbol of symbols. Beauty reveals everything, because it expresses nothing. When it shows us itself, it shows us the whole fiery-coloured world.
quotes.Title: Irish Poet
quotes.Name: Oscar Wilde

quotes.Text: The development of language is part of the development of the personality, for words are the natural means of expressing thoughts and establishing understanding between people.
quotes.Title: Italian Educator
quotes.Name: Maria Montessori

quotes.Text: Everybody has a creative potential and from the moment you can express this creative potential, you can start changing the world.
quotes.Title: Brazilian Novelist
quotes.Name: Paulo Coelho

quotes.Text: O public road, I say back I am not afraid to leave you, yet I love you, you express me better than I can express myself.
quotes.Title: American Poet
quotes.Name: Walt Whitman

quotes.Text: When I was 8 years old, it mattered what my favorite singer said and wore and expressed opinions about.
quotes.Title: American Singer
quotes.Name: Taylor Swift

quotes.Text: Music expresses that which cannot be said and on which it is impossible to be silent.
quotes.Title: French Author
quotes.Name: Victor Hugo

quotes.Text: Character is expressed through our behavior patterns, or natural responses to things.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Joyce Meyer
